question:
A company has an AWS Lambda function that needs read access to an Amazon S3 bucket that is located in the same AWS account.

Which solution will meet these requirements in the MOST secure manner?

options.A: Apply an S3 bucket policy that grants read access to the S3 bucket.
options.B: Apply an IAM role to the Lambda function. Apply an IAM policy to the role to grant read access to the S3 bucket.
options.C: Embed an access key and a secret key in the Lambda function's code to grant the required IAM permissions for read access to the S3 bucket.
options.D: Apply an IAM role to the Lambda function. Apply an IAM policy to the role to grant read access to all S3 buckets in the account.

explanation: Using an IAM role with a policy granting read access to the specific S3 bucket follows the principle of least privilege - most secure approach. Embedded credentials are insecure and not recommended. Granting access to all S3 buckets violates least privilege. Bucket policies alone don't authenticate the Lambda function - IAM roles provide the identity.
